Definition 1.2.2.

For s≥0𝑠0s\geq 0 we consider the Falconer functional Fs:SL⁡(d,ℝ)→ℝ:subscript𝐹𝑠→SL𝑑ℝℝF_{s}:\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R})\to\mathbb{R} by:

and define the Falconer dimension dimF(ρ)subscriptdimension𝐹𝜌\dim_{F}(\rho) of ρ𝜌\rho to be its critical exponent:

Definition 1.2.3.

Let ρ:Γ→SL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜌→ΓSL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) be a linear representation and p∈⟦1,d−1⟧𝑝1𝑑1p\in\llbracket 1,d-1\rrbracket. We say that ρ𝜌\rho is p𝑝p-Anosov if there exist constants μ,C>0𝜇𝐶0\mu,C>0 such that for all γ∈Γ𝛾Γ\gamma\in\Gamma:

Chapter 2 Upper bound

2.1 Proof of bound

Lemma 2.1.1 (Upper bound for dimension).

Let ρ:Γ→SL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜌→ΓSL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) be a projective Anosov representation. Then:

dimH(ξ1​(∂Γ))≤dimF(ρ).subscriptdimension𝐻superscript𝜉1Γsubscriptdimension𝐹𝜌\dim_{H}(\xi^{1}(\partial\Gamma))\leq\dim_{F}(\rho).
Remark 2.1.1.

The idea of the proof of Lemma 2.1.1 is to find a covering whose Hausdorff content is dominated by the Dirichlet series of some functional ΨspsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑠𝑝\Psi_{s}^{p}, which will in turn imply that dimH(ξ1​(∂Γ))≤hρ​(Ψp)subscriptdimension𝐻superscript𝜉1Γsubscriptℎ𝜌superscriptΨ𝑝\dim_{H}(\xi^{1}(\partial\Gamma))\leq h_{\rho}(\Psi^{p}). Choosing then the most "effective" cover (i.e. the one which yields the smallest Hausdorff content up to a constant) we obtain that

dimH(ξ1​(∂Γ))≤hρ​(maxp⁡Ψp)subscriptdimension𝐻superscript𝜉1Γsubscriptℎ𝜌subscript𝑝superscriptΨ𝑝\dim_{H}(\xi^{1}(\partial\Gamma))\leq h_{\rho}(\max_{p}\Psi^{p})

To obtain this we first cover ξ1​(∂Γ)superscript𝜉1Γ\xi^{1}(\partial\Gamma) by the bassins of attraction ρ​(γ)⋅Bα1,α​(ρ​(γ))⋅𝜌𝛾subscript𝐵subscript𝛼1𝛼𝜌𝛾\rho(\gamma)\cdot B_{\alpha_{1},\alpha}(\rho(\gamma)) for γ∈Γ𝛾Γ\gamma\in\Gamma satisfying |γ|=T𝛾𝑇|\gamma|=T. Then we cover each bassin by an ellipsoid of axes lengths

1sin⁡(α)​σ2σ1​(ρ​(γ)),…,1sin⁡(α)​σdσ1​(ρ​(γ)).1𝛼subscript𝜎2subscript𝜎1𝜌𝛾…1𝛼subscript𝜎𝑑subscript𝜎1𝜌𝛾\frac{1}{\sin(\alpha)}\frac{\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}}(\rho(\gamma)),\ldots,\frac{1}{\sin(\alpha)}\frac{\sigma_{d}}{\sigma_{1}}(\rho(\gamma)).

Finally we cover each ellipsoid by balls of some fixed radius r>0𝑟0r>0. It can be shown by comparing the series appearing in the Hausdorff content of each resulting cover that the most "effective" choice of r𝑟r depends only on the Hausdorff exponent s>0𝑠0s>0 and in any case will be to have r𝑟r equal (up to a constant) to the the length of an axis of the ellipsoid, i.e.

r∈{1sin⁡(α)σ2σ1(ρ(γ)),…,1sin⁡(α)σdσ1(ρ(γ)).}r\in\left\{\frac{1}{\sin(\alpha)}\frac{\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}}(\rho(\gamma)),\ldots,\frac{1}{\sin(\alpha)}\frac{\sigma_{d}}{\sigma_{1}}(\rho(\gamma)).\right\}

In particular, when s∈[p−2,p−1]𝑠𝑝2𝑝1s\in[p-2,p-1], the most effective choice is r=σp​(ρ​(γ))/σ1​(ρ​(γ))𝑟subscript𝜎𝑝𝜌𝛾subscript𝜎1𝜌𝛾r=\sigma_{p}(\rho(\gamma))/\sigma_{1}(\rho(\gamma)), whose Hausdorff content is dominated by the Dirichlet series of ΨspsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑠𝑝\Psi_{s}^{p}.

Proof of Lemma 2.1.1.

Let p∈⟦2,d⟧𝑝2𝑑p\in\llbracket 2,d\rrbracket. Then using Proposition 2.2.1, Lemma 2.2.2, and Lemma 2.2.3 we have that for T>0𝑇0T>0 large enough, ξ1​(∂Γ)superscript𝜉1Γ\xi^{1}(\partial\Gamma) is covered by the family

𝒰T={ρ​(γ)​Bα1,α​(ρ​(γ)):|γ|=T},subscript𝒰𝑇conditional-set𝜌𝛾subscript𝐵subscript𝛼1𝛼𝜌𝛾𝛾𝑇\mathcal{U}_{T}=\left\{\rho(\gamma)B_{\alpha_{1},\alpha}(\rho(\gamma)):|\gamma|=T\right\},

and that each basin ρ​(γ)​Bα1,α​(ρ​(γ))𝜌𝛾subscript𝐵subscript𝛼1𝛼𝜌𝛾\rho(\gamma)B_{\alpha_{1},\alpha}(\rho(\gamma)) is in turn covered by

2p−2⋅σp​(g)p−2σ2​(g)​⋯​σp−1​(g)⋅superscript2𝑝2subscript𝜎𝑝superscript𝑔𝑝2subscript𝜎2𝑔⋯subscript𝜎𝑝1𝑔2^{p-2}\cdot\frac{\sigma_{p}(g)^{p-2}}{\sigma_{2}(g)\cdots\sigma_{p-1}(g)}

many balls of radius

By the definition of the Hausdorff measure, for s≥0𝑠0s\geq 0:

To see that the above implies the upper bound, consider some s>dimF(ρ)𝑠subscriptdimension𝐹𝜌s>\dim_{F}(\rho). By the definition of the Falconer dimension, this implies that the Dirichlet series corresponding to the Falconer functional converges:

and in particular

∎

3.1 Proof strategy

Denoting with dΓ=dimHξρ1​(∂Γ)subscript𝑑Γsubscriptdimension𝐻superscriptsubscript𝜉𝜌1Γd_{\Gamma}=\dim_{H}\xi_{\rho}^{1}(\partial\Gamma) the Hausdorff dimension of the limit set, we shall outline how to obtain its lower bound by the Falconer dimension

dΓ≥hρ​(F).subscript𝑑Γsubscriptℎ𝜌𝐹d_{\Gamma}\geq h_{\rho}(F).

First we recall that Fs​(a)=max⁡{Ψsp​(a):p∈⟦2,d⟧}subscript𝐹𝑠𝑎:superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑠𝑝𝑎𝑝2𝑑F_{s}(a)=\max\{\Psi_{s}^{p}(a):p\in\llbracket 2,d\rrbracket\} and in particular hρ​(F)≤hρ​(ΨdΓ+1)subscriptℎ𝜌𝐹subscriptℎ𝜌superscriptΨsubscript𝑑Γ1h_{\rho}(F)\leq h_{\rho}(\Psi^{d_{\Gamma}+1}). Thus the lower bound will follow once we have shown that

dΓ≥hρ​(ΨdΓ+1).subscript𝑑Γsubscriptℎ𝜌superscriptΨsubscript𝑑Γ1d_{\Gamma}\geq h_{\rho}(\Psi^{d_{\Gamma}+1}).

Noting that (s+1)​JdΓu≥Ψs+dΓdΓ+1𝑠1subscript𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑑Γ𝑢superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑠subscript𝑑Γsubscript𝑑Γ1(s+1)J_{d_{\Gamma}^{u}}\geq\Psi_{s+d_{\Gamma}}^{d_{\Gamma}+1}, the above bound will follow as soon as we have shown that

hρ​(JdΓ)≥1.subscriptℎ𝜌subscript𝐽subscript𝑑Γ1h_{\rho}(J_{d_{\Gamma}})\geq 1. (LB)

To obtain Equation LB, one uses the method of Patterson-Sullivan-Quint, which may be summed up in

There exists a ​(ϕ,ρ)​-Patterson-Sullivan measure on ​ℱΘ​(ℝd)⇒hρ​(ϕ)≥1,⇒There exists a italic-ϕ𝜌-Patterson-Sullivan measure on subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscriptℎ𝜌italic-ϕ1\displaystyle\text{There exists a }(\phi,\rho)\text{-Patterson-Sullivan measure on }\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\Rightarrow h_{\rho}(\phi)\geq 1,

where ϕ∈𝔞Θitalic-ϕsubscript𝔞Θ\phi\in\mathfrak{a}_{\Theta} and Θ⊆ΠΘΠ\Theta\subseteq\Pi. The property that we will need of our measure is that there exists a collection of open sets Uγγ∈Γsubscriptsubscript𝑈𝛾𝛾Γ{U_{\gamma}}_{\gamma}\in\Gamma such that

μ​(Uγ)∼e−JdΓu​(a​(ρ​(γ)))​ and ​M:=supn∈ℕmax⁡{♯​A:A⊆Γn,⋂γ∈AUγ≠∅}<∞similar-to𝜇subscript𝑈𝛾superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐽subscript𝑑Γ𝑢𝑎𝜌𝛾 and 𝑀assignsubscriptsupremum𝑛ℕ:♯𝐴formulae-sequence𝐴subscriptΓ𝑛subscript𝛾𝐴subscript𝑈𝛾\displaystyle\mu(U_{\gamma})\sim e^{-J_{d_{\Gamma}}^{u}(a(\rho(\gamma)))}\text{ and }M:=\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\max\left\{\sharp A:A\subseteq\Gamma_{n},\bigcap_{\gamma\in A}U_{\gamma}\neq\emptyset\right\}<\infty (MP)

where Γn={γ∈Γ:|γ|=n}subscriptΓ𝑛conditional-set𝛾Γ𝛾𝑛\Gamma_{n}=\{\gamma\in\Gamma:|\gamma|=n\}. The existence of a (JdΓu,ρ)superscriptsubscript𝐽subscript𝑑Γ𝑢𝜌(J_{d_{\Gamma}}^{u},\rho)-Patterson-Sullivan measure that satisfies the property (MP) will be proved in Section 3.2. Assuming that for the time being, below we outline the Patterson-Sullivan-Quint method of obtaining Equation LB.

Indeed, we first obtain the uniform in n𝑛n bound:

∑γ∈Γne−JdΓu​(a​(ρ​(γ)))≲∑γ∈Γnμ​(ρ​(Uγ))≤1M​μ​(ℱΘ​(ℝd))<∞less-than-or-similar-tosubscript𝛾subscriptΓ𝑛superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐽subscript𝑑Γ𝑢𝑎𝜌𝛾subscript𝛾subscriptΓ𝑛𝜇𝜌subscript𝑈𝛾1𝑀𝜇subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\sum_{\gamma\in\Gamma_{n}}e^{-J_{d_{\Gamma}}^{u}(a(\rho(\gamma)))}\lesssim\sum_{\gamma\in\Gamma_{n}}\mu(\rho(U_{\gamma}))\leq\frac{1}{M}\mu(\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}))<\infty

along with the bound implied by the Anosov property of ρ𝜌\rho:

JdΓ​(a​(ρ​(γ)))≥𝖺12​(a​(ρ​(γ)))≥C​|γ|−bsubscript𝐽subscript𝑑Γ𝑎𝜌𝛾subscript𝖺12𝑎𝜌𝛾𝐶𝛾𝑏\displaystyle J_{d_{\Gamma}}(a(\rho(\gamma)))\geq\mathsf{a}_{12}(a(\rho(\gamma)))\geq C|\gamma|-b

to conclude that

∑γ∈Γe−(s+1)​JdΓu​(a​(ρ​(γ)))subscript𝛾Γsuperscript𝑒𝑠1subscriptsuperscript𝐽𝑢subscript𝑑Γ𝑎𝜌𝛾\displaystyle\sum_{\gamma\in\Gamma}e^{-(s+1)J^{u}_{d_{\Gamma}}(a(\rho(\gamma)))} =∑n≥0∑γ∈Γne−s​JdΓu​(a​(ρ​(γ)))​eJdΓu​(a​(ρ​(γ)))≲∑n≥0e−s​(C​n−b)<∞absentsubscript𝑛0subscript𝛾subscriptΓ𝑛superscript𝑒𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐽𝑢subscript𝑑Γ𝑎𝜌𝛾superscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝐽𝑢subscript𝑑Γ𝑎𝜌𝛾less-than-or-similar-tosubscript𝑛0superscript𝑒𝑠𝐶𝑛𝑏\displaystyle=\sum_{n\geq 0}\sum_{\gamma\in\Gamma_{n}}e^{-sJ^{u}_{d_{\Gamma}}(a(\rho(\gamma)))}e^{J^{u}_{d_{\Gamma}}(a(\rho(\gamma)))}\lesssim\sum_{n\geq 0}e^{-s(Cn-b)}<\infty

which holds for any s>0𝑠0s>0, and thus Equation LB holds.

3.2 Existence of Patterson-Sullivan measure

Definition 3.2.1.

Proposition 3.2.1.

Assume that ξρ1​(∂Γ)subscriptsuperscript𝜉1𝜌Γ\xi^{1}_{\rho}(\partial\Gamma) is a Lipschitz submanifold of dimension dΓsubscript𝑑Γd_{\Gamma}. and

xdΓ+1=π−1​(Tξρ1​(x)​ξρ1​(∂Γ))​ξρ1​(x)∈𝒢dΓ+1​(ℝd),superscript𝑥subscript𝑑Γ1superscript𝜋1subscript𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝜉1𝜌𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝜉1𝜌Γsubscriptsuperscript𝜉1𝜌𝑥subscript𝒢subscript𝑑Γ1superscriptℝ𝑑x^{d_{\Gamma}+1}=\pi^{-1}(T_{\xi^{1}_{\rho}(x)}\xi^{1}_{\rho}(\partial\Gamma))\xi^{1}_{\rho}(x)\in\mathcal{G}_{d_{\Gamma}+1}(\mathbb{R}^{d}),

for which one can show that

Before giving the next definition, we recall that the annihilator annihilator of an element y∈ℱF​i​Θ​(ℝd)𝑦subscriptℱ𝐹𝑖Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑y\in\mathcal{F}_{F}{i\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) is the set of partial flags that are not transverse to y𝑦y, that is:

Definition 3.2.2.

Let ρ:Γ→SL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜌→ΓSL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) be a linear representation, Θ⊆ΠΘΠ\Theta\subseteq\Pi and μ𝜇\mu a measure over ℱΘ​(ℝd)subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}). We say that ρ𝜌\rho is μ𝜇\mu-irreducible there is no element in ℱi​Θ​(ℝd)subscriptℱ𝑖Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}_{i\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}), whose annihilator is of full measure, i.e. for all y∈ℱi​Θ​(ℝd)𝑦subscriptℱ𝑖Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑y\in\mathcal{F}_{i\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}):

μ​(Ann​(y))<μ​(ℱΘ​(ℝd)).𝜇Ann𝑦𝜇subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mu(\mathrm{Ann}(y))<\mu(\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d})).
Example 3.2.1.

If ρ​(Γ)𝜌Γ\rho(\Gamma) is Zariski-dense in SL⁡(d,ℝ)SL𝑑ℝ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}), then ρ𝜌\rho is μ𝜇\mu-irreducible for any ρ𝜌\rho-quasi-equivariant measure μ𝜇\mu, and in particular for any (ρ​(Γ),ϕ)𝜌Γitalic-ϕ(\rho(\Gamma),\phi)-Patterson-Sullivan measure.

Remark 3.2.1.

The reason that we introduce the concept of μ𝜇\mu-irreducibility is that for any μ𝜇\mu-irreducible representation ρ:Γ→SL⁡d,ℝ:𝜌→ΓSL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}{d,\mathbb{R}}, there exist α,κ>0𝛼𝜅0\alpha,\kappa>0 such that μ​(BΘ,α​(ρ​(γ)))≥k𝜇subscript𝐵Θ𝛼𝜌𝛾𝑘\mu(B_{\Theta,\alpha}(\rho(\gamma)))\geq k for all γ∈Γ𝛾Γ\gamma\in\Gamma.

Indeed, if this were not the case, then there would exists a sequence αn↘0↘subscript𝛼𝑛0\alpha_{n}\searrow 0 and γn∈Γsubscript𝛾𝑛Γ\gamma_{n}\in\Gamma such that

μ​(Bθ,α​(ρ​(γ)))≤1n.𝜇subscript𝐵𝜃𝛼𝜌𝛾1𝑛\mu(B_{\theta,\alpha}(\rho(\gamma)))\leq\frac{1}{n}.

Due to the compactness of ℱΘ​(ℝd)subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}), up to considering a subsequence, we may assume that the reppeling flags or ρ​(γn)𝜌subscript𝛾𝑛\rho(\gamma_{n}) converge to some ξ∈ℱΘ​(ℝd)𝜉subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\xi\in\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}):

(Ud−i​(ρ​(γn)−1))𝖺i∈Θ→ξ→subscriptsubscript𝑈𝑑𝑖𝜌superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛1subscript𝖺𝑖Θ𝜉(U_{d-i}(\rho(\gamma_{n})^{-1}))_{\mathsf{a}_{i}\in\Theta}\to\xi

In that case, the complements BΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γn))superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾𝑛B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{n})) will converge to the annihilator of ξ𝜉\xi, in the sense:

lim supnBΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γn))⊆Ann​(ξ).subscriptlimit-supremum𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾𝑛Ann𝜉\limsup_{n}B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{n}))\subseteq\mathrm{Ann}(\xi).

Indeed, let y∈lim supnBΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γn))𝑦subscriptlimit-supremum𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾𝑛y\in\limsup_{n}B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{n})) and consider a subsequence knsubscript𝑘𝑛k_{n} such that y∈BΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γkn))𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾subscript𝑘𝑛y\in B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{k_{n}})). By the very definition of BΘ,αn​(ρ​(γn))subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝜌subscript𝛾𝑛B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}(\rho(\gamma_{n})), there exists some p𝑝p such that up to considering a subsequence of knsubscript𝑘𝑛k_{n},

holds. Taking the limit as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty, we have that yp∩ξd−p≠0superscript𝑦𝑝superscript𝜉𝑑𝑝0y^{p}\cap\xi^{d-p}\neq 0 and hence y∈Ann​(ξ)𝑦Ann𝜉y\in\mathrm{Ann(\xi)}.

Using a measure-theoretic arguement we conclude that Ann​(ξ)Ann𝜉\mathrm{Ann}(\xi) is of full measure, which contradicts the μ𝜇\mu-irreducibility of ρ𝜌\rho:

μ​(Ann​(ξ))≥μ​(lim supnBΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γkn)))≥lim supnμ​(BΘ,αnc​(ρ​(γkn)))=μ​(ℱΘ​(ℝd)).𝜇Ann𝜉𝜇subscriptlimit-supremum𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾subscript𝑘𝑛subscriptlimit-supremum𝑛𝜇superscriptsubscript𝐵Θsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑐𝜌subscript𝛾subscript𝑘𝑛𝜇subscriptℱΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mu(\mathrm{Ann}(\xi))\geq\mu(\limsup_{n}B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{k_{n}})))\geq\limsup_{n}\mu(B_{\Theta,\alpha_{n}}^{c}(\rho(\gamma_{k_{n}})))=\mu(\mathcal{F}_{\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d})).
Lemma 3.2.1.

Let ρ:Γ→SL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜌→ΓSL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) be a representation and μϕsuperscript𝜇italic-ϕ\mu^{\phi} be a (ρ​(Γ),ϕ𝜌Γitalic-ϕ\rho(\Gamma),\phi)-Patterson-Sullivan measure. Appendix A Tangent space to the Grassmanian

Let V𝑉V be a d𝑑d-dimensional real vector space. We denote with 𝒢k​(V)subscript𝒢𝑘𝑉\mathcal{G}_{k}(V) the Grassmanian of k𝑘k-dimensional subspaces of V𝑉V. Our first objective is to find a convenient way to express its tangent space.

Proposition A.0.1.

We have the following canonical identification:

hom⁡(W,V/W)hom𝑊𝑉𝑊\displaystyle\hom(W,V/W) ≃TW​𝒢k​(V)similar-to-or-equalsabsentsubscript𝑇𝑊subscript𝒢𝑘𝑉\displaystyle\simeq T_{W}\mathcal{G}_{k}(V)
ϕitalic-ϕ\displaystyle\phi ↦dd​t|t=0​Γ​(t​ϕ)maps-toabsentevaluated-atdd𝑡𝑡0Γ𝑡italic-ϕ\displaystyle\mapsto\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}\Big{|}_{t=0}\Gamma(t\phi)

where Γ​(ϕ)=(I​d+ϕ)​(W)Γitalic-ϕ𝐼𝑑italic-ϕ𝑊\Gamma(\phi)=(Id+\phi)(W) is the graph of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi.

Proof.

We will consider the map

whose derivative is given by:

Appendix B Irreducible actions problem

The matter of this chapter has to do with an obstruction, found in the proof of this lemma:

Lemma B.0.1 (Lemma 6.8 in [PSW23]).

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a hyperbolic group and η:Γ→PGL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜂→ΓPGL𝑑ℝ\eta:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{PGL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) be a strongly irreducible projective Anosov representation such that ξη​(∂Γ)subscript𝜉𝜂Γ\xi_{\eta}(\partial\Gamma) is homeomorphic to SdΓsuperscript𝑆subscript𝑑ΓS^{d_{\Gamma}}, and which admits a measurable η𝜂\eta-equivariant section ζ:∂Γ→ℱ{𝖺𝟣,𝖺𝖽Γ+𝟣}​(ℝd):𝜁→Γsubscriptℱsubscript𝖺1subscript𝖺subscript𝖽sans-serif-Γ1superscriptℝ𝑑\zeta:\partial\Gamma\to\mathcal{F}_{\{\sf a_{1},\sf a_{d_{\Gamma}+1}\}}(\mathbb{R}^{d}). Then η𝜂\eta is μ𝜇\mu-irreducible for any (η​(Γ),ϕ)𝜂Γitalic-ϕ(\eta(\Gamma),\phi)-Patterson-Sullivan measure μ𝜇\mu on ℱ{𝖺𝟣,𝖺𝖽Γ+𝟣}​(ℝd)subscriptℱsubscript𝖺1subscript𝖺subscript𝖽sans-serif-Γ1superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}_{\{\sf a_{1},\sf a_{d_{\Gamma}+1}\}}(\mathbb{R}^{d}).

For convenience, we recall that a linear representation ρ:Γ→GL⁡(d,ℝ):𝜌→ΓGL𝑑ℝ\rho:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(d,\mathbb{R}) is strongly irreducible if there is no proper ρ​(Γ)𝜌Γ\rho(\Gamma)-invariant subspace of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, and it is μ𝜇\mu-irreducible if there is no element in ℱi​Θ​(ℝd)subscriptℱ𝑖Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}_{i\Theta}(\mathbb{R}^{d}), whose annihilator is of full measure.

In what follows, we will show that the above lemma is false, by providing a counterexample. Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a uniform lattice of SU⁡(2,1)SU21\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1) (i.e. acts convex cocompactly ), and η:Γ→SL⁡(𝔰​𝔲​(2,1)):𝜂→ΓSL𝔰𝔲21\eta:\Gamma\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(\mathfrak{su}(2,1)) be the restriction of the adjoint representation, i.e. η​(γ)=Adγ𝜂𝛾subscriptAd𝛾\eta(\gamma)=\operatorname{Ad}_{\gamma} for all γ∈Γ𝛾Γ\gamma\in\Gamma.

For convenience, we recall the definition of a uniform lattice:

Definition B.0.1.

Let G𝐺G be a locally compact group. A uniform lattice is a discrete subgroup Γ≤GΓ𝐺\Gamma\leq G that is co-compact, i.e. G/Γ𝐺ΓG/\Gamma is compact.

Remark B.0.1.

When G=Isom⁡(X)𝐺Isom𝑋G=\operatorname{Isom}(X) is the isometry group of a complete Riemannian manifold X𝑋X, and ΓΓ\Gamma is a uniform lattice of G𝐺G,then it acts properly discontinuously and cocompactly on X𝑋X.

We begin by showing proving the Anosov property of η𝜂\eta.

Proposition B.0.1.

η𝜂\eta is projective Anosov.

Proof.

Let γ∈Γ𝛾Γ\gamma\in\Gamma. Since γ∈SU⁡(2,1)𝛾SU21\gamma\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1), we have that

γ=k1​exp⁡(r​(γ)​x0)​k2𝛾subscript𝑘1𝑟𝛾subscript𝑥0subscript𝑘2\gamma=k_{1}\exp\left(r(\gamma)x_{0}\right)k_{2}

for x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} a fixed non-zero in the Weyl-chamber ℝ​x0ℝsubscript𝑥0\mathbb{R}x_{0} of 𝔰​𝔲⁡(2,1),r​(γ)∈ℝ𝔰𝔲21𝑟𝛾ℝ\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(2,1),r(\gamma)\in\mathbb{R} and k1,k2∈U⁡(2)subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2U2k_{1},k_{2}\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{U}}}(2). Then by the definition of a uniform lattice, we have that ΓΓ\Gamma acts properly discontinuously and cocompactly, which means that the inclusion Γ↪SU⁡(2,1)↪ΓSU21\Gamma\hookrightarrow\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1) is projective Anosov (since SU⁡(2,1)SU21\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1) is of rank 1). Before giving an expression for the projective part of the limit map of η𝜂\eta, we make a few observations regarding Gromov boundary of ΓΓ\Gamma. In particular, we claim that since ΓΓ\Gamma is a uniform lattice os SU⁡(2,1)SU21\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1), we have that ∂ΓΓ\partial\Gamma is homeomorphic to SU⁡(2,1)/PSU21𝑃\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1)/P, where P𝑃P is a parabolic subgroup of SU⁡(2,1)SU21\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1), and it coincides with the stabilizer of some isotropic line l∈∂∞ℍℂ2𝑙subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂl\in\partial_{\infty}\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}}.

Indeed, for a uniform lattice ΓΓ\Gamma of the isometry group G𝐺G of a homogenous G𝐺G-space X𝑋X, the Milnor-Švarc lemma implies that for any x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in X, the map Γ→X,γ↦γ​x0formulae-sequence→Γ𝑋maps-to𝛾𝛾subscript𝑥0\Gamma\to X,\gamma\mapsto\gamma x_{0} is a quasi-isometry. In our case G=SU⁡(2,1)𝐺SU21G=\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1) and X=ℍℂ2𝑋subscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂX=\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}} is a hyperbolic metric space, so it the quasi-isometry extends to a homeomorphism ∂Γ→∂Hℂ2→Γsubscriptsuperscript𝐻2ℂ\partial\Gamma\to\partial H^{2}_{\mathbb{C}} of the Gromov-boundaries. On the other hand, the action of SU⁡(2,1)SU21\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1) on ∂∞ℍℂ2subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂ\partial_{\infty}\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}} is transitive, so we have that ∂ℍℂ2≃SU⁡(2,1)/Psimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂSU21𝑃\partial\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}}\simeq\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1)/P where P𝑃P is the stabilizer of a point in ∂ℍℂ2subscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂ\partial\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}}. In fact, we have that P𝑃P is a parabolic subgroup of S​U​(2,1)𝑆𝑈21SU(2,1). The combination of the above, along with the fact that the geometric and the Gromov boundaries agree in the case of ℍℂ2subscriptsuperscriptℍ2ℂ\mathbb{H}^{2}_{\mathbb{C}}, we deduce that ∂Γ≃SU⁡(2,1)/Psimilar-to-or-equalsΓSU21𝑃\partial\Gamma\simeq\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2,1)/P.44todo: 4Add proofs of these.

We now proceed to calculate the projective part of the limit map of η𝜂\eta.

Proposition B.0.2.
